column3: ACK, though as long as we have at least a GCC before 10.0 in our CI, such identifiers won't work regardless.\n\n Note that this flag also does not exist for clang (which seems to have no way of disallowing such identifiers, or non-ascii input in general).

Concept ACK. The same is enforced for the python functional tests (emojis in symbol names are not allowed by python, but strings may contain arbitrary utf-8 characters).\n\nEdit: It looks like python3 does allow some non-ascii unicode: https://docs.python.org/3/reference/lexical_analysis.html#identifiers

> ACK, though as long as we have at least a GCC before 10.0 in our CI, such identifiers won't work regardless.\n\nYou're right with regard to CI. Then it's mostly useful for people developing locally, I suppose. I tend to prefer problems being flagged while compiling locally to having to PR and wait for travis to fail.

The gcc 10 release notes kindly include an example to test against https://gcc.gnu.org/gcc-10/changes.html
